title: How did the Gauls view the Romans? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first recorded encounter between Romans and the Gaulish people was during the Second Punic War, when Gallic mercenaries rallied under the banner of the Carthaginian general Hannibal Barca. Needless to say, that wasn't the most cordial of ways to begin international relations. The Romans eventually subdued the Gauls to conquer the southern areas of present-day France in 121, this area dubbed Gallia Narbonensis. By 51 B.C.E, almost all of the Gallic Empire was claimed by Julius Caesar. The native Gallic tribes almost never saw the Romans in a friendly light. They were constantly in a conflict with them, records indicating assassinations and massacres of the sort happening on both sides. In fact, even centuries after the Roman conquest of Gaul, there came a massive rebellion. The Batavian general Postumus briefly created a breakaway state from the Roman Empire during the crisis of the third century. As time went by, however, Roman culture and traditions seeped into Gallic ways and the two fused together. A variant of Vulgar Latin was produced, and an age of Gallo-Roman culture ensued. After some time, Roman identities stuck with the Gallic peoples, who by this time considered themselves to be Romans. This sense of self-identity persisted even after the fall of the Western Roman Empire, the various regions of Gaul maintaining a distinct Roman culture until the 6th Century A.D.

It really depends on the era and the particular group of Gauls. Brennus and his group who sacked Rome in 399 BCE probably viewed Rome with distain. As Rome expanded north some Gauls liked what Rome brought and others did not. This is especially true when Caesar conquered Gaul. I imagine most were awed by Rome…some liked what Rome offered, and some hated Rome. As Rome was incorporated into the empire many saw great benefit in being part of the empire.

Before the time of Julius Caesar: As either intrusive aliens or potential strong allies or wealthy but soft city dwellers to trade with and occasionally to rip off good style; Between the time of Julius Caesar and the time of Caracalla: As either unwelcome conquerors or important allies who were a crucial source of funding and trade. (the number in the former category declined towards zero and the number in the latter category grew correspondingly over this period of nearly 300 years); After the time of Caracalla: As fellow citizens.
